newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- JUNE 5.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS- JUNE 5.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:

--Labour and Social Security Minister Miltiades Papaioannou yesterday came out strongly against any merger of bank pensions fund with main social security pension fund, IKA. "There will be no merger to the cost of IKA. This is a position I will defend whatever cost it has, governmental or political," he said.

--State inflows continued their disappointing performance again in May, with figures expected to show rates of 11.5 percent compared to forecast 15.6 percent and despite the beginning of intensive tax checks.

--Inflation was floating at the 5.0 percent mark in May according to reports, bringing joy to the government's economic team and hope that the budget target of 4.5 percent by year's end was within reach.
--Labour minister Papaioannou will start chasing both state and private sector debtors to IKA whose combined bill comes close to 650 billion drachmas.
--Greek taxpayers declared a combined income of 11 trillion drachmas in 1995 and paid 23.2 percent more tax. The total tax bill for taxpayers was 628.6 billion drachmas, officials said.
--The Greek economy is on stable economic ground, according to London-based IBCA risk evaluation company, which upgraded the Greek economy to BBB.
--State inflows were up by 13.6 percent in the January-May period, according to the Bank of Greece, close to the 14.8 percent forecast in the budget.

--The Bank of Greece drained 250 billion drachmas at yesterday's fixed-rate tender, bringing interest rates up by 0.80 percent. The bank is reported to be concerned about international market speculation on the drachma if they are not convinced by statements by the new French government on the future of European Union.
--The new price of shares offered by OTE, Greece's telecoms organisation, will be determined over the next few days by the finance ministry.

--The non-payment of fines by those constructing illegal buildings was to a great degree responsible for the lag in public inflows last month, according to a meeting at the national economy ministry yesterday. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
